evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observable and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t2_interim dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t2_interim, with no contradictory evidence undermining this root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t2_interim, such as timing, involved personnel, and context of the incident.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is observable and documented in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t2_interim dataset.

assumptions: The dataset Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_pair_engine_t2_interim corresponds to the provided history items H1-H9
The described interactions and observations in the history items reflect communication/coordination breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew with no breakdown
If the incident was primarily caused by procedural deviation or environmental/marking deficiencies rather than communication failure

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 document observable communication and coordination issues among crew during pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown in the dataset. The discriminator payloads indicate this supports R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN over procedural deviation or marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting whether communication issues were the primary cause versus procedural or environmental factors

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim dataset.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim data.

assumptions: The TRP marking described in H7 corresponds to the environmental or marking deficiency referenced in the claim.
Statements about visual signals in H8 relate to marking adequacy and visibility.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and adequate to prevent the incident, or if procedural deviations were the sole cause without marking issues.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the presence and location of the TRP marking relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, and H8 indicates the marking's visibility and adequacy were questioned, supporting the presence of an environmental or marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether marking visibility alone caused the incident versus procedural errors
